subsection.title: Linearity properties of coordinate vectors
subsection.p: Here we finally record the linearity properties of the coordinate vector process.

statement.p:
Suppose \basisfont{B} is a basis of a finite-dimensional vector space V. Then we have the following patterns concerning coordinate vectors relative to \basisfont{B}.
The coordinate vector of a sum is the sum of the coordinate vectors. That is, \rmatrixOf{\uvec{v} + \uvec{w}}{B} = \rmatrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B} + \rmatrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B} for each pair of vectors \uvec{v},\uvec{w} in V.
The coordinate vector of a scalar multiple is the scalar multiple of the coordinate vector. That is, \rmatrixOf{k \uvec{v}}{B} = k \rmatrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B} for each scalar k and each vector \uvec{v} in V.
The coordinate vector of a linear combination is the corresponding linear combination of the coordinate vectors. That is,
\rmatrixOf{k_1 \uvec{v}_1 + k_2 \uvec{v}_2 + \dotsc + k_m \uvec{v}_m}{B} = k_1 \rmatrixOf{\uvec{v}_1}{B} + k_2 \rmatrixOf{\uvec{v}_2}{B} + \dotsc + k_m \rmatrixOf{\uvec{v}_m}{B}
for each collection of scalars k_1,k_2,\dotsc,k_m and each collection of vectors \uvec{v}_1,\uvec{v}_2,\dotsc,\uvec{v}_m in V.

remark.p: Note that in each of the statements of , there are different vector operations in use on either side of the equals sign on the left the vector operation(s) within the coordinate-vector brackets are those used in the vector space V, while on the right the vector operation(s) used between the coordinate-vector brackets are those used in \R^n. For example, if V is a space of polynomials, then the plus sign in the notation \rmatrixOf{\uvec{v} + \uvec{w}}{B} means addition of polynomials (because that's what \uvec{v} and \uvec{w} are), while the plus sign in the expression \rmatrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B} + \rmatrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B} means addition of vectors in \R^n (because thats what \rmatrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B} and \rmatrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B} are).

subsection.title: Properties of transition matrices
subsection.p:
Here we record and prove those properties explored in
and further discussed in , as well as this initial uniqueness statement.

statement.p: For each pair of bases \basisfont{B},\basisfont{B}' of an n-dimensional vector space V, there exists one unique n \times n matrix P such that P \matrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B} = \matrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B'} holds for every vector \uvec{v} in V.

proof.p:
We already know from our discussion in
that such a matrix exists, so we need to prove that only \ucobmtrx{B}{B'} is capable of converting between coordinate vectors relative to these two bases.

So suppose that P is an n \times n matrix such that
P \matrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B} = \matrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B'}
holds for every vector \uvec{v} in V. In particular, it must then hold for every vector in \basisfont{B}. Write \basisfont{B} = \{ \uvec{u}_1, \uvec{u}_2, \dotsc, \uvec{u}_n \} . Now, it easy to write one of the vectors in \basisfont{B} as a linear combination of these basis vectors. For example, \uvec{u}_1 = 1 \uvec{u}_1 + 0 \uvec{u}_2 + \dotsb + 0 \uvec{u}_n , which says that \rmatrixOf{\uvec{u}_1}{B} = \uvec{e}_1, the first standard basis vector of \R^n. So if we take \uvec{v} = \uvec{u}_1 in
above, we get P \uvec{e}_1 = \matrixOf{\uvec{u}_1}{B'} . Now, we have seen a couple of times ( ) that a matrix times a standard basis vector produces the corresponding column of the matrix. In the above, P times the first standard basis vector of \R^n produces the first column of P. From this we conclude that the first column of P must be \matrixOf{\uvec{u}_1}{B'} , which coincidentally is the same as the first column of \ucobmtrx{B}{B'}.

If we repeat this argument with \uvec{v} = \uvec{u}_2 in , we arrive at the conclusion that the second column of P must be \matrixOf{\uvec{u}_2}{B'} , which coincidentally is the same as the second column of \ucobmtrx{B}{B'}. And so on, running through all the vectors of \basisfont{B}, until we have concluded that every column of P is the same as the corresponding column in \cobmtrx{B}{B'}, at which point we can also conclude that P = \ucobmtrx{B}{B'} .

statement.p:
In the following, assume \basisfont{B}, \basisfont{B}', and \basisfont{B}'' are bases of a finite dimensional vector space V.
The transition \basisfont{B} \to \basisfont{B} is trivial. That is, \ucobmtrx{B}{B} = I , the identity matrix.
A chain of transitions \basisfont{B} \to \basisfont{B}', \basisfont{B}' \to \basisfont{B}'' combine to a single transition \basisfont{B} \to \basisfont{B}''. That is, \ucobmtrx{B'}{B''} \ucobmtrx{B}{B'} = \ucobmtrx{B}{B''} .
The transition \basisfont{B}' \to \basisfont{B} is the reverse of the transition \basisfont{B} \to \basisfont{B}'. That is, \ucobmtrx{B'}{B} = \uinvcobmtrx{B}{B'} .

ol.li: says that \ucobmtrx{B}{B} is the one unique matrix so that \ucobmtrx{B}{B} \matrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B} = \matrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B} holds for every vector \uvec{v} in V. But clearly also I \matrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B} = \matrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B} holds for every vector \uvec{v} in V, so we must have I = \ucobmtrx{B}{B}, as desired.

To prove that a matrix is the inverse of another, we only need to show that they multiply to the identity in one order ( and ). And the first two statements of this proposition tell us that \ucobmtrx{B'}{B} \ucobmtrx{B}{B'} = \ucobmtrx{B}{B} = I , so that we indeed have \ucobmtrx{B'}{B} = \uinvcobmtrx{B}{B'} , as desired.

proof.p: This fact follows immediately from Statement of .

subsection.title: Change of basis in \R^n
subsection.p: Finally, we record an observation from .

statement.p: Every invertible matrix is somehow a transition matrix between bases of \R^n.

proof.p: If P is an invertible matrix, then its columns form a basis of \R^n (Statement of ). Let \basisfont{B} represent that basis. Then the columns of the transition matrix \ucobmtrx{B}{S} (where \basisfont{S} is the standard basis of \R^n as usual) are just the vectors in \basisfont{B}. Therefore, \ucobmtrx{B}{S} = P, as desired.
